text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.51.4, LB&I Case Management, LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement (FTS) Program.
IRM 4.51.4.1.3: Added reference to the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

(BBA) cases. (

) Organizational titles updated. (

This IRM supersedes IRM 4.51.4 dated June 28, 2017.
LB&I, Appeals

LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS) 4.51.4 page 1
Scope (

) Purpose : Fast Track Settlement (FTS) was developed as an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) process that furthers the Service’s goal of resolving tax controversies fairly and impartially to both the government and the taxpayer in an expeditious manner. A primary objective of the Service is to resolve tax differences at the earlier stages of the exam without sacriﬁcing the quality integrity of the examination. FTS improves business practices by addressing disputes as early as possible to expedite case closing and reduce taxpayer burden. FTS provides LB&I and taxpayers an opportunity to resolve their disputes with an Appeals Official using mediation skills and settlement authority. (
) Audience : The primary users of this IRM are LB&I and Appeals. (

) Policy Owner . The Strategy, Policy and Governance Office (SPG) of the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration (ADCCI) and the Independent Office of Appeals jointly manage and administer the FTS Program. (
) Program Owner : LB&I ADCCI SPG is responsible for updating IRM
) Rev. Proc.
C.B.
, formally established the FTS Program, with the goal of expediting case resolutions and expanding the range of dispute resolution options available to taxpayers. (

Purpose : Fast Track Settlement (FTS) was developed as an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) process that furthers the Service’s goal of resolving tax controversies fairly and impartially to both the government and the taxpayer in an expeditious manner. A primary objective of the Service is to resolve tax differences at the earlier stages of the exam without sacriﬁcing the quality and integrity of the examination. FTS improves business practices by addressing disputes as early as possible to expedite case closing and reduce taxpayer burden. FTS provides LB&I and taxpayers an opportunity to resolve their disputes with an Appeals Official using mediation skills and settlement

) SPG and the IRS Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals) work jointly to minister the FTS Program. (
) The IRS Independent Office of Appeals is the official FTS recordkeeper originator of the data. (
) SPG reports monthly on FTS cases to LB&I stakeholders. (
) The SPG director, program managers and team managers work together provide oversight for the FTS program. (
) The SPG analyst prepares the FTS LB&I monthly and annual reporting to stakeholders within LB&I. (
) The IRS adopted the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in June
Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accordance with taxpayer rights. Se
RC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer For additional information about TBOR, see Publication
, Taxpayer Bill Rights and https://www.irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights . Objectives (
) Fast Track Settlement will enable taxpayers and the IRS to work together resolve outstanding issues while the case remains in LB&I jurisdiction. (

) FTS program is designed to: a. Resolve examination issues at the earliest stage b. Leverage Appeals settlement authority and mediation skills c. Decrease overall time from return ﬁling to case closure d. Ensure process meets the needs of the LB&I population e. Reduce taxpayer burden with optimal use of Service resources Reports (

) Appeals is responsible for FTS data collection and FTS reporting. The data provided by Appeals monthly to SPG. The primary purpose of the data is provide monthly updates on FTS cases received, in-process and closed to stakeholders. Tracking (
) The Issue Management System (IMS) is the primary LB&I tracking tool for FTS, and it is important to accurately and timely complete appropriate FTS ﬁelds in the IMS system. (

) The following ﬁelds have been established within IMS “Issue Resolution at the Technical Issue level to track and monitor the FTS program in LB&I: a. “Fast Track Considered” – a “Yes” in this ﬁeld if Fast Track was consid- ered and “No” if it was not. b. “Territory Manager Concurrence”– this ﬁeld is required (and will become enabled) if “Fast Track Considered” is “No” c. “Fast Track Settlement” – a “Yes” in this ﬁeld indicates that FTS was used. Fast Track Settlement will enable taxpayers and the IRS to work together to resolve outstanding issues while the case remains in LB&I jurisdiction.
The following ﬁelds have been established within IMS “Issue Resolution Tools” at the Technical Issue level to track and monitor the FTS program in LB&I:
“Fast Track Considered” – a “Yes” in this ﬁeld if Fast Track was consid

ered and “No” if it was not. “Territory Manager Concurrence”– this ﬁeld is required (and will become enabled) if “Fast Track Considered” is “No” “Fast Track Settlement” – a “Yes” in this ﬁeld indicates that FTS was used.
LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS) 4.51.4 page

d. “Fast Track Settlement Start Date” - Date that FTS is initiated (application submitted and accepted). e. “Fast Track Settlement End Date” – Date FTS process is completed either with a signed agreement or by conclusion that agreement cannot be reached. f. “Fast Track Settlement Offered and Refused” – A “Yes” in this ﬁeld indicates that FTS was offered, but declined by the taxpayer. (
) At a minimum, FTS data on IMS should be updated when the FTS process initiated and when it is completed. Resources (
) The Fast Track Settlement web pages at https://www.irs.gov/appeals/fast-track and https://irssource.web.irs.gov/LBI/Lists/ADCCIPMO/Dis
te
orm.aspx?ID=
contain many tools and links designed to help LB&I personnel understand and participate in this process. FTS (
) FTS takes place while the case is in LB&I jurisdiction and is designed to be completed within approximately

days from when Appeals accepts the application. LB&I, the taxpayer, and Appeals are active participants in the process, and all three must agree before a proposed resolution can be imple- mented. FTS uses mediation techniques to lead LB&I and the taxpayer to determine the likely outcome of the dispute. When a resolution cannot be reached through mediation, Appeals may propose a resolution, but such proposal cannot be imposed on either party. If the Fast Track Settlement process is unsuccessful, Appeals may not issue a statutory notice, and the taxpayer retains its traditional appeals rights. Since the process would have occurred under LB&I jurisdiction, the case remains with LB&I for disposition. (

) While FTS makes Appeals settlement authority available if needed, LB&I can mediate and resolve factual issues within its existing resolution authority without requiring Appeals settlement authority. For these issues not requiring settlement authority, Appeals will work to resolve the issue via a mediated agreement between the taxpayer and LB&I. For these issues, Appeals will generally not draft or execute a closing agreement. (

) Issues involving legal interpretations generally require the consideration of hazards of litigation. For these issues, Appeals will ﬁrst work to mediate an agreement that falls within an acceptable range as determined by an analysis of the litigating hazards. Once an acceptable agreement is reached, the Appeals official will accept the settlement in a closing agreement that ﬁnalizes the resolution of the issues. Appeals will make its own evaluation of the hazards pertaining to the issue and will only execute a settlement agreement that falls within an acceptable range. Prior to the FTS referral, LB&I must not commit, or appear to commit, to a settlement with the taxpayer that exceeds LB&I’s authority. For issues requiring settlement authority, Appeals will analyze the hazards of litigation in the same manner as would be done in the tradi- tional Appeals process.
, Integrity in Selection (
) Policy Statement
applies to the Fast Track Process in primarily three main areas: Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS)
page
“Fast Track Settlement Start Date”

Date that FTS is initiated (application submitted and accepted). “Fast Track Settlement End Date” – Date FTS process is completed either with a signed agreement or by conclusion that agreement cannot be reached. “Fast Track Settlement Offered and Refused” – A “Yes” in this ﬁeld indicates that FTS was offered, but declined by the taxpayer.

Ensure fairness to the taxpaying public – By offering FTS to all LB&I taxpayers with applicable disputed issues we ensure fairness to the taxpaying public which promotes public conﬁdence in our tax system for all taxpayers. Ensure an equitable process for all taxpayers – FTS is offered to the taxpayer for each disputed issue on an LB&I case, when applicable. A mandatory note is placed in the case activity record documenting the FTS offer. This provides a safeguard that is built into our enforcement processes to ensure that FTS is offered impartially and consistently to each taxpayer. Ensure fairness to each taxpayer – An LB&I taxpayer can use the FTS option to resolve the case dispute sooner than the normal Appeals process. Offering FTS to all applicable taxpayers ensures each taxpayer is getting the same due process options.
Note: Issues that are not applicable to taxpayers and that are ineligible for FTS are described in IRM

) FTS may be initiated at any time after an issue has been fully developed but must be initiated prior to the issuance of the
-day letter. (
) “Fully developed” will generally be indicated by: a. The issuance of a Notice of Proposed Adjustment (Form

) to the taxpayer clearly setting out the Government’s determination and the and factual basis upon which it is made. b. A written response from the taxpayer clearly stating its position and the basis for disagreement (

) With the concurrence of the Appeals FTS program manager and the LB&I issue/case territory manager, an issue may be accepted when it is adequately developed to facilitate resolution, even though it may not be developed to extent required for a revenue agent report (RAR). (

) When considering the use of FTS, it is recommended that the LB&I issue manager (in collaboration with the case manager) contact his/her territory managers and/or the FTS program managers to discuss the case/issues. taxpayer may participate in such discussion via conference call, at the discre- tion of the issue/case manager. (
) FTS can be used, if applicable, when Appeals releases jurisdiction of a case consider new information or new issues. (

LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS) 4.51.4 page
Considerations (

) The LB&I issue manager (in collaboration with the case manager) and the taxpayer will evaluate their individual circumstances to determine if this process meets their needs to bring the case to conclusion within the agreed upon time frames. (
) Fast Track Settlement may not be the appropriate dispute resolution process for all cases. (
) The LB&I issue manager (in collaboration with the case manager) and taxpayer should explore other dispute resolution options if a case is deter- mined to be ineligible or inappropriate for FTS. (

) The greatest opportunity to reduce administrative burden and costs for all parties using FTS exists in cases where: a. All issues are raised, and the examination process is nearly complete b. All claims are timely ﬁled and examined c. Issues are fully developed d. Taxpayer has stated its position in writing e. Unagreed issues are limited in number (

) FTS process works best in cases where all unagreed issues are included the application, however: a. Individual unagreed issues or groups of issues will be accepted for in cases where it is determined to be in the best interest of tax adminis- tration. b. Acceptance of individual issues may be limited due to availability of Appeals resources. (
) When FTS is unsuccessful in resolving all issues, the taxpayer will be the opportunity to pursue resolution through traditional Appeals. (
) If the taxpayer pursues the traditional Appeals process, Appeals management will ensure a fair and impartial hearing. IRM

, Terminating the FTS Session, states that the traditional appeal will not be assigned to the same ATCL or AO that heard the FTS session, unless concurrence is in writing from the taxpayer and LB&I prior to assignment. This policy should be made clear to the taxpayer at the beginning of the process, and if the taxpayer is unable to accept this policy, the taxpayer may decide to forego Fast Track option and go to traditional Appeals. Note: Post Appeals Mediation is not available for cases that were previously mediated through a different alternative dispute resolution program within Appeals, such as Fast Track Settlement. (See Rev. Proc.
). Cases (
) Generally, cases worked under the jurisdiction of LB&I are eligible for FTS. (

) Under limited circumstances, cases with unique characteristics requiring special handling may be accepted for FTS with approval of the Appeals program managers and the LB&I issue/case territory manager. These cases include: a. Cases involving taxpayers in bankruptcy where LB&I follows the provi- sions of IRM
, Bankruptcy - Examiner Responsibilities and Procedures, regarding notiﬁcation to Chief Counsel and Department LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS)

The decision to reduce the liability in the proof of claim rests with LB&I, in accordance with Chief Counsel and Department of Justice guidelines. b. Cases involving Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of

(TEFRA) procedures where the ﬁrst level entity and the major controlling shareholder/partners are included in the Fast Track Session. LB&I will complete the required TEFRA administrative proceedings, including Notice of Proposed Adjustment (NOPA), Notice of Beginning Administra- tive Proceedings (NBAP), and Notice of Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment (FPAA) procedures for all levels, including investor statutes. Appeals will provide an Appeals official to conduct the Fast Track Session at the ﬁrst entity level and help the parties reach a settlement. A Waiver on Assessment Form

-PT (AD) type of agreement will be used to secure agreement from the entity and controlling shareholders/ partners. Closing agreements are not normally used in TEFRA cases but may be used at the option of the parties. c. Cases involving the Bipartisan Budget Act of

(BBA) procedures where the ﬁrst level entity is included in the Fast Track Session. LB&I will complete the required BBA administrative proceedings, including Notice of Administrative Proceedings (NAP), Notice of Proposed Partnership Ad- justment (NOPPA/PPA), and Notice of Final Partnership Adjustment (FPA) procedures. Appeals will provide an Appeals official to conduct the Fast Track Session at the ﬁrst entity level and help the parties reach a settle- ment. d. Joint Committee cases using procedures under IRM
and IRM

) The following cases/issues are generally not appropriate for the Fast Track Settlement Program: a. Docketed issues b. Issues challenging the constitutionality of tax laws c. Cases/issues for which the taxpayer has expressed unwillingness to com- promise or explore a mutual concession resolution (

) The following issues will be excluded from FTS: a. Issues designated for litigation b. Issues under consideration to be designated for litigation c. Issues for which the taxpayer has ﬁled a request for competent authority assistance d. Issues for which the taxpayer has requested the simultaneous Appeal/ Competent Authority procedure described in section
of Rev. Proc.

e. Issues that are part of a whipsaw transaction f. Issues for which mediation would not be consistent with sound tax admin- istration g. Issues that have been identiﬁed in a Chief Counsel Notice, or equivalent publication, as excluded from the FTS process h. Issues raised by taxpayer challenging the validity of a regulation (
) Issues speciﬁcally excluded under (
) above will result in the exclusion of the entire case.

) Issues for which the Service is in the process of establishing a uniform settle- ment position (e.g. - certain listed transactions) may be excluded from FTS. (
) LB&I and Appeals have established joint operating procedures for the case application, submissions, screening and resolution processes. (
) LB&I and Appeals procedures are covered by IRM
and IRM
, respectively. (
) Additional procedures applicable only to the Appeals function for FTS cases may be found in IRM
) Fast Track Settlement is premised on the basis that the LB&I issue/case manager and taxpayer have exhausted existing issue resolution strategies available within LB&I. (

) Fast Track Settlement is an ADR initiative which must be considered by the LB&I issue/case manager when there are unagreed issues which cannot be resolved between the taxpayer and the examination team. FTS consideration and conclusions reached will be documented in the case activity record. (
) The taxpayer should be provided with a copy of the Fast Track Settlement
at the opening conference or they may obtain a copy at https://www.irs. gov/pub/irs-pdf/p
pdf . (
) Consideration of FTS could occur at any phase of the examination process when LB&I anticipates disagreement on an issue. (

) At a minimum, the potential use of Fast Track should be discussed and docu- mented at the following points in the examination process where applicable: a. Opening conference (meeting) (documented within the agenda and/or corporate interview) b. Mid-cycle risk analysis (documented within Form
, Risk Analysis Worksheet) c. When potentially unagreed issues are proposed (documented within Form
and/or Form
-A) d. Update to document and upload documents in IMS per IRM

to the taxpayer before the taxpayer submits its application for FTS. (
) Participation in FTS does not preclude the taxpayer from requesting traditional Appeals consideration if the FTS process is not successful in resolving the case. See IRM
, Terminating the LB&I FTS Session. (

) The LB&I issue/case manager will explain the Fast Track Settlement process to the taxpayer and determine whether the case qualiﬁes for Fast Track Settle- ment using the case eligibility and exclusion criteria of IRM

) The LB&I and Appeals program managers are available to assist the parties determining whether the case is suitable for the FTS process. (
) If the case does not qualify for FTS, the standard examination procedures closing process are to be followed. (
) Any request for FTS denied to the taxpayer by the LB&I issue/case manager, requires concurrence of the LB&I issue/case territory manager. (

) In all cases, the case manager will forward a copy of any denied request, along with a brief statement as to the reasons for denial, to the LB&I issue/ case territory manager. A pro forma memo requesting territory manager concurrence with Fast Track denial is contained at Exhibit
A completed copy of this memo will be maintained in the case ﬁle. Approval (
) When Form
, Application for Fast Track Settlement, is signed by the taxpayer, the case manager and the appropriate LB&I territory manager, the referring LB&I case manager will email Form
, Form
(s) and the written response to the unagreed issue from the taxpayer to the FTS mailbox at *AP ATCL FTS with an information copy to LB&I FTS coordinator. (
) The Appeals FTS program manager, in coordination with the LB&I FTS program manager, will screen the application to ensure the case is appropriate for FTS. (

) Acceptance or rejection of an FTS application will be based on a review of formation submitted, discussions with the LB&I issue/case manager, and the recommendation of the assigned Appeals team manager (ATM). (
) The Appeals program manager will determine availability of Appeals staffing resources before accepting the case. (
) If accepted, the LB&I case manager and the taxpayer will be contacted by assigned appeals officer within ten days of receipt of the application. (

) Any case started without concurrence of both the Appeals Fast Track program manager and the LB&I issue/case territory manager will, at the discretion of either manager, be treated as a withdrawn case. If a case is not accepted the FTS Program, the LB&I issue/case territory manager and Appeals FTS program managers will jointly notify the LB&I issue/case manager(s) and the taxpayer within ten days of receipt of the application. (
) The FTS process is limited to
calendar days, unless the LB&I issue/case territory manager and the Appeals Fast Track program manager agree to an extension. (

) The LB&I issue/case manager, in consultation with the Appeals official, will determine the LB&I participants. In addition to the issue/case manager, pants will generally include the team coordinator and/or revenue agents developed the issue(s). Depending on the issue(s), the case manager may also request the participation of specialists. of (

) When issues are identiﬁed as potentially appropriate for FTS by either the taxpayer or the examination team, the LB&I issue/case manager will discuss the issues and case with the taxpayer. Discussions should include: a. Suitability of issues for the FTS process b. Willingness of both parties to consider alternative resolution options c. Adequacy of issue development d. Ability of both parties to devote resources to the process (

) The LB&I issue manager (in collaboration with the case manager) should discuss the case with the LB&I issue/case territory manager, the LB&I FTS program manager and/or the Appeals FTS program manager before initiating the Fast Track application process. (

) The LB&I case manager and the taxpayer will identify a preferred conference site, and Appeals will make every attempt to hold the Fast Track session ference at the preferred site, but may not in all cases be able to honor the taxpayer/LB&I request. (
) Upon reaching agreement to participate in the Fast Track Settlement process, both the taxpayer and LB&I case manager will jointly complete and sign Form
, Application for Fast Track Settlement. (
) When the Form

is ready for submission and is signed by the appropri- ate LB&I territory manager, the referring LB&I case manager will email the application to the FTS mailbox at *AP ATCL FTS with a copy to the LB&I program coordinator. (
) The Appeals Fast Track program manager will notify the ATM about the cation, and the ATM will pre-assign an ATCL or AO to the case. (
) Since LB&I retains jurisdiction for the case and responsibility for the statute, the case manager will not forward the case ﬁle to Appeals. Application Fast Track to Managers (

) The LB&I Fast Track Settlement Application Issue Statement will contain scriptive name of the issue being referred, the Uniform Issue List (UIL) number, dollar amounts by year, and a brief statement of basis for the proposed adjustment and the taxpayer’s basis for disagreement. FTS (

) Agents can “close their case” for monitoring purposes while applying the program to resolve unagreed issues. Agents can use the FTS program, doing so would cause a case to exceed its estimated completion date (
) For FTS cases where all other examination issues are resolved except for or more FTS issues, agents should use AIMS/ERCS Status Code
with Aging Reason Code
Cases with AIMS/ERCS Status Code
and Aging Reason Code
will be considered “closed” for monitoring purposes. (
) If all issues are resolved and the ECD is within the practice area’s recommen- dation, except for the FTS issue(s), then the ECD may be extended up to additional
days on IMS to account for additional time necessary to complete FTS. Follow the practice area’s speciﬁc procedures for obtaining approval to extend the ECD. (
) This section discusses the general procedures to be followed by Appeals personnel regarding the FTS application, acceptance and case assignment processes. (
) Speciﬁc Appeals procedures are outlined in IRM
in (
) Appeals functions in a mediation role to guide LB&I and the taxpayers to mutually acceptable resolution. (
) Appeals plays an active role in the issue resolution process. (
) Appeals may advocate a resolution position but cannot impose such on either party. (
) Once an agreement is reached, Appeals will use its settlement authority implement the agreed-upon resolution. (
) FTS cases are assigned to appeals officers, as listed below: a. Primarily assigned to a Grade
ATCL trained in mediation b. In limited cases, assigned to Grade
appeals officers, trained in mediation (
) The Appeals FTS team may include Appeals Technical Specialists for ACI when appropriate. (
) Other appeals officers will be assigned to the team as needed, and at the cretion of the ATCL/ATM. (

) Appeals may use mediation-trained individuals from other divisions as co- mediators when their speciﬁc insight and technical knowledge of the issue being considered would make such participation beneﬁcial to resolution of issue.

This section discusses the general procedures to be followed by Appeals personnel regarding the FTS application, acceptance and case assignment
for Fast Cases (

) In most cases, the Appeals FTS program manager will alert the ATM that a Fast Track Settlement case is being sent to the local office. When time permits, the ATM and Appeals FTS program manager will pre-assign an Appeals official to the case. (

) Within three business days of receipt, the ATM will review the application to determine if the FTS eligibility requirements are met. The ATM may involve ATCL or other Appeals official in the review. (
) If the ATM determines the case is eligible, the ATM must contact the Appeals FTS program manager to discuss acceptance of the case. (

) The ATM will indicate acceptance of the case by signing the application form. The Appeals FTS program manager and the LB&I issue/case territory manager will consider the ATM’s recommendation, along with other factors, in deciding whether to accept case for FTS. (
) If the ATM/ATCL does not recommend acceptance of the case, this will be communicated to the Appeals FTS program manager, who may assign the plication to another ATCL for a second review. (

) Any case started without the approval of either the Appeals FTS program manager or the LB&I issue/case territory manager will, at the discretion of respective managers, be treated as a withdrawn case. (
) Except with the concurrence of the LB&I issue/case territory manager and Appeals FTS program managers, the FTS process is limited to
days. The start date for the
-day Fast Track process is the date the Appeals official accepts the FTS application. Accepted for (

) Issues referred for FTS resolution should be fully developed. Requests for Technical Advice, Field Service Advice, etc. will not be made during the FTS process. Cases requiring further issue development are not ready for FTS, the ATM will recommend rejection accordingly. (

) If the ATM determines that the case does not qualify for FTS (e.g. issues not fully developed, issues do not qualify, Appeals resources are not available, issues excluded), the ATM will discuss the rationale for the denial with the Appeals FTS program manager. (
) Appeals FTS program manager may concur with the recommended denial of the FTS request or may accept the case and identify necessary resources. (

) If the FTS request is recommended for rejection, the Appeals FTS program manager will discuss the rationale for rejection with the LB&I issue/case territory manager and the LB&I FTS program manager. (
) The program managers will discuss the rationale for the denial with the taxpayer and LB&I case/issue manager within ten business days of receipt the application. for Fast Assigned in (
) The Appeals FTS program manager will notify the LB&I case/issue manager acceptance or denial of the FTS Application within
business days of Appeals receipt of the FTS application. Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS)

) After the Form

, Application for Fast Track Settlement, is accepted LB&I issue/case territory manager and Appeals FTS program managers, ATM will assign an appeals officer or an ATCL within seven business days receipt of the application. (
) Appeals will normally accommodate the site jointly requested by the LB&I manager and the taxpayer. (

) Where travel or personnel resource limitations impose restrictions on Appeals ability to accommodate the requested site, approval of the Appeals FTS program manager is required to use an alternative site. (
) The ATM and ATCL shall coordinate the need to use a team of appeals officers. (

) Where the case includes Appeals specialty issues, the appeals officer or will follow IRM requirements to refer the issues to the Appeals Director Operations or Appeals Director International Operations. Such referral shall initiated by telephone and followed up with a formal written referral. The Appeals technical specialist may be assigned if warranted. (
) Request may be made to Appeals management for speciﬁc assignment of appeals officers with experience or technical expertise involving the issue. Role (
) Within ten business days after the case is assigned, the Appeals official call the taxpayer and LB&I case manager to start the Fast Track session planning process. (
) The Appeals official may identify and discuss the need to limit the number participants to the Fast Track session. (
) Fast Track cases are excluded from the Settlement Authority Panel Review because LB&I must agree to any disposition of the issues. in (
) Where an issue is coordinated as an ACI issue, the Appeals team should follow the procedures in IRM

) To meet the two-pronged requirement that all decision makers are present the Fast Track session and that ACI issues are subject to the review and currence of the Appeals technical specialist, the Appeals technical specialist will normally serve as a team member and will participate in the Fast Track session with the taxpayer and LB&I. (

) If the Appeals technical specialist is not part of the Fast Track Appeals settlement of the ACI issue remains subject to the review and concurrence the Appeals technical specialist. This may be accomplished via telephone cussion. (
) If there is a disagreement between the Appeals technical specialist and the appeals officer on appropriate settlement terms for the issue, the resolution procedures in IRM
will be followed.

) of LB&I Participants in Fast Sessions (

) The LB&I issue manager (in collaboration with the case manager) will: a. Determine the composition of the LB&I Fast Track team b. Serve as LB&I’s decision maker for all issues under FTS consideration Note: However, at the discretion of LB&I, decision making authority be assumed by a higher level LB&I management official who ticipates in the session. c. Attend all FTS session meetings and consider information and arguments presented by issue specialists for all parties (

) Personnel selected by the issue/case manager to be part of the LB&I team will: a. Be the primary presenters of LB&I’s position and technical arguments issues under consideration b. When appropriate, provide rebuttals to arguments raised by the taxpayer c. Provide consultation and advice to the LB&I decision maker regarding proposed settlements (

) If LB&I Counsel representatives are part of the LB&I Fast Track team, their primary role will be to provide advice to LB&I as to legal interpretations and appropriateness of proposed settlements. At the discretion of the LB&I issue manager, Counsel may participate in the presentation of the LB&I position technical arguments for the issues under consideration.
) Introduction to the Fast Session (
) The Fast Track session encompasses all activities from the date the case accepted through the date of the face-to-face session(s) involving all parties.
) Planning the Fast Track Session (

) Planning begins after the case is assigned and the Fast Track Settlement plication is accepted by Appeals. The Appeals official will call the taxpayer LB&I case manager to start the Fast Track session planning process. (
) The parties are encouraged to bring their technical experts into the Fast Settlement process. It is required that the “decision makers” be present. (
) Appeals will lead the taxpayer and LB&I to develop an overall plan for the Track session. The plan will include the preparation of an agenda and Form
, Fast Track Session Report (IRM

The LB&I issue manager (in collaboration with the case manager) will:
The Fast Track session encompasses all activities from the date the case is accepted through the date of the face-to-face session(s) involving all parties.
The parties are encouraged to bring their technical experts into the Fast Track Settlement process. It is required that the “decision makers” be present.
In conducting the Fast Track Session, the Appeals official will use a Form 14000, Fast Track Session Report and an agenda. The agenda will guide the
) The Appeals official will provide the Fast Track Session Report and agenda all decision makers early the process, and will update them as the session gresses. Fast (
) The Fast Track session will be led by Appeals, but all three parties will be active participants with equal voices. (
) FTS employs various alternative dispute resolution techniques to propose solutions. (
) Appeals does not perform in a traditional Appeals role but will ﬁrst use an interest-based approach to facilitate a settlement of the issues between the parties. (
) Using mediating techniques, Appeals will attempt to bring the parties to a mutual resolution of the issues during the Fast Track session. (

) As issues are resolved, Appeals will post the results to the Fast Track Report and give an updated copy to all participants. Appeals will maintain history of the updated Fast Track Session Report. (
) The Fast Track Session may include both combined meetings with LB&I, taxpayer and Appeals together, and separate meetings (LB&I-Appeals, and taxpayer-Appeals) as appropriate. (
) Appeals may use various methods and techniques to meet the needs and cumstances of each case. (

) The Appeals official may ultimately make recommendations regarding the settlement of any or all issues (both factual and legal). If acceptable to all parties, the settlement proposal may be adopted. (
) Neither party is compelled to accept a settlement proposal made by the Appeals official. (

) For an Appeals settlement proposal to be implemented, both LB&I and the taxpayer must agree. If the taxpayer and Appeals agree to a settlement proposal, but the LB&I issue/case manager rejects the proposal, the issue/ case manager’s position will be referred to the LB&I issue/case territory manager for review. (

) If the LB&I issue/case territory manager concurs with the proposed settlement rejection, the rejection must be expressed in writing by the territory manager. an acceptable alternative settlement cannot be reached, the issue will be closed unagreed. If the issue/case territory manager does not concur in rejecting the Appeals settlement proposal, the proposal will be accepted by LB&I. (
) The prohibition on ex parte communications between appeals officers and other Internal Revenue Service employees provided by section
) the Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of
does apply to the communications arising in Fast Track Settlement, because the Appeals personnel are not acting in their traditional appeals settlement role. See Rev. Proc.

of (

) If the taxpayer or LB&I presents new information during the Fast Track session that the opposing party has not considered, Appeals will give the receiving party adequate time to evaluate the information/documentation. (

) Where consideration of substantial new information will unduly delay the Fast Track session, the case may be withdrawn from FTS by either Appeals, LB&I or the taxpayer. The case may be reconsidered for FTS after the issues are fully developed. (

) In situations where substantial new information is introduced during the FTS process, such new information may serve as a basis to raise a new issue or ﬁle a claim. The new information may be accepted into the FTS process subject to limitations discussed under IRM
However, such accep- tance may only take place if it would not delay the FTS process beyond the planned
days, and if all parties concur in the acceptance of the new infor- mation. Fast (

) Experience proves that lapse time is doubled when new issues or claims are brought into Fast Track Settlement after the process is started. For this reason, new issues or claims will generally not be accepted as part of the FTS process. (

) The grounds for raising a new issue or claim must be substantial, and the potential effect on the tax liability must be material. New issues or claims should not be raised to trade against existing issues. (
) A taxpayer’s claim requires LB&I examination action. However, such action need not be part of the FTS process. (
) New, unrelated claims or new issues should not be attached to an existing FTS process but should generally be considered in a separate process outside of FTS. (
) The parties will work to resolve the issues originally referred to Fast Track Settlement and the FTS process will not be suspended to allow examination the new claims/issues. (

) If the taxpayer declines to bring the Fast Track process to a conclusion prior consideration of such claims, the Service will withdraw the case from FTS. taxpayer may then request further FTS consideration. (

) Once a case comes to FTS, the taxpayer and Service should expect that all the issues and claims have been raised, that all relevant information has been disclosed, and that the case is ready for resolution. (

) Addressing this challenge, and to prevent new issues arriving late in the process, the Appeals official shall conﬁrm that all issues are listed on the Fast Track Session Report at the beginning of the process. Fast Report (
) Form
, Fast Track Session Report, is an administrative document that assists all parties in planning the Fast Track session and reports the progress on the issues in dispute. (
) At the conclusion of the process, the Fast Track Session Report forms the basis for drafting closing agreements and the revenue agent’s report (RAR). Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS)

At the conclusion of the process, the Fast Track Session Report forms the basis for drafting closing agreements and the revenue agent’s report (RAR).

) The Fast Track Session Report is used to identify the issues and reﬂect agreement from all parties as to the following: a. Number of issues b. Description of issues c. Amounts in dispute d. Conference dates e. Plan of action to be followed in the Fast Track session process (

) In addition to documenting all contacts in the Appeals Centralized Data System (ACDS) activity record and conference notes, the Appeals official will prepare the Fast Track Session Report (Session Report) at the start of the Fast Track Process, and update the Session Report timely as decisions are made. (

) The Appeals official will: a. Give both taxpayer and LB&I a copy of the Session Report at the beginning of the process, after each decision is reached and when the Session Report is updated, b. Conﬁrm that the parties agree with the entries on the Session Report, and, c. Solicit the signatures of the taxpayer and LB&I issue/case manager on the Session Report at the conclusion of the session (agreed or unagreed). (

) The signing of the Fast Track Session Report does not constitute a ﬁnal ment. The signature on the Fast Track Session Report carries no more force and effect than a memorandum of understanding between the parties. (

) The Fast Track Session Report is not a waiver of restrictions on assessment, nor does it terminate consents to extend the statute of limitation, nor does it start the running of any statute of limitations, i.e. - one-year statute under
(f) involving TEFRA proceedings. (
) The signature of a Service official on the Fast Track Session Report does create a promise against reopening the case. of Fast Report (

) The Fast Track Session Report Agreement shall be treated as ﬁnal when it signed, unless the speciﬁc conditions outlined below warrant altering the agreement. a. If an agreement is reached in a signed Fast Track Settlement Session Report, but a subsequent authoritative decision is rendered that affects the agreement in a substantive and material manner, either LB&I or Appeals may reconsider the agreement unless both the taxpayer and Appeals previously signed a closing agreement (Form
) or a Form

-AD). b. If the change is substantive and material, the agreement should be gotiated. The word substantive shall mean that the change in law or precedent results in a meaningful change to Appeals assessment of hazards of litigation. c. Any agreement reached in a Fast Track Settlement session may be reopened in the case of fraud, malfeasance, concealment or misrepre- sentation of material fact.

a. ) or a Form

-AD). b. If the change is substantive and material, the agreement should be rene- gotiated. d. The grounds for such action must be substantial (strong, possessing merit) and the potential effect on the tax liability is material (having real importance and great consequence). e. NEW ISSUES - There must be some sound substantial grounds already existing in the record or known to the decision maker to raise the new issue. f. Substantial grounds are those that cause a decision maker to be quite certain, at the time a new issue is raised, that the Government will if the issue is litigated. Quite certain does not necessarily mean

percent certain, but it does mean a very high degree of certainty. g. Outside of these strict parameters, LB&I and Appeals shall respect the settlement terms agreed to on the Fast Track Session Report. (
) Appeals commits to advocate the agreement reached in a signed Fast Track Session Report to reviewing authorities, such as the Joint Committee on Taxation. (

) In the event of a request to reconsider the Fast Track Session Report agreement, the LB&I and Appeals FTS program managers must agree to re- consider the agreement. In the event the two parties are unable to agree, decision shall be elevated to the executive owners of the Fast Track Settle- ment process.
) Appeals or LB&I May Terminate the Fast Track Session (
) If after a reasonable time, it is apparent that no further beneﬁt may be derived from the process, the LB&I issue/case manager and/or the Appeals official should consider terminating the session. (
) If the Appeals official decides to terminate the Fast Track session, concurrence of the Appeals FTS program manager is required. (
) If the LB&I issue/case manager decides to terminate the Fast Track session, concurrence of the appropriate territory manager is required. (
) The party terminating the Fast Track session shall notify the other parties by letter explaining the reason for termination and outlining the taxpayer’s right a traditional Appeals process. (
) If no issues have been resolved prior to withdrawal, no further reporting to taxpayer or LB&I by Appeals will be required. (
) If some issues have been resolved at the time of withdrawal, standard FTS process closing procedures will be followed regarding the resolved issues. (
) The taxpayer will retain all standard Appeals rights regarding any issues remaining unresolved at the time of withdrawal.
) Taxpayer May Withdraw at Any Time (
) The taxpayer may withdraw from the FTS process at any time by notifying LB&I case manager and the Appeals representative in writing. (
) For any issue(s) that remain unresolved, taxpayers will retain all standard Appeals rights. (

) LB&I will close the case as “unagreed” or “partially agreed” as appropriate forward the case to Appeals upon receipt of an acceptable protest along with the taxpayer’s request for an Appeals hearing. LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS)

d. The grounds for such action must be substantial (strong, possessing real merit) and the potential effect on the tax liability is material (having real importance and great consequence). e. NEW ISSUES - There must be some sound substantial grounds already existing in the record or known to the decision maker to raise the new issue. f. Substantial grounds are those that cause a decision maker to be quite certain, at the time a new issue is raised, that the Government will prevail if the issue is litigated. Quite certain does not necessarily mean

percent certain, but it does mean a very high degree of certainty. g. Outside of these strict parameters, LB&I and Appeals shall respect the settlement terms agreed to on the Fast Track Session Report.
If the Appeals official decides to terminate the Fast Track session, concurrence of the Appeals FTS program manager is required.
If the LB&I issue/case manager decides to terminate the Fast Track session, concurrence of the appropriate territory manager is required.
If some issues have been resolved at the time of withdrawal, standard FTS process closing procedures will be followed regarding the resolved issues.
) The taxpayer should be advised that the case will be closed through the standard LB&I closing process. Settlement (
) Appeals has settlement authority under IRM
, Delegation Order
(formerly Delegation Order
, Rev.
). Also see Delegation Order
, Authority of Appeals to Administer Alternative Dispute Resolution Procedures. (
) An Appeals official, such as an ATCL, Appeals team manager, or an appeals officer (no lower than a Grade
), uses delegated settlement authority to approve and enter into any FTS Agreement that involves hazards of litigation by using a Speciﬁc Matters Closing Agreement (Form
) or a waiver Form
-AD. (

) Appeals makes its own evaluation of the hazards on Fast Track issues. LB&I should not commit or appear to commit to a settlement that exceeds their authority to resolve issues prior to referral to Fast Track settlement. (

) Potential settlement positions that may have been discussed with the taxpayer before an FTS referral may be presented to the Appeals official for consider- ation during the Fast Track session. However, Appeals will do an independent evaluation of the hazards and will not execute a settlement that does not fall within such hazards evaluation or established settlement guidelines for the issue. (
) If the Appeals official does not accept a settlement proposed between the taxpayer and LB&I, the official will fully explain to both parties why it cannot accepted. (

) If a Joint Committee report is required for the case, Appeals will delay execution of the closing agreement until LB&I completes the Joint Committee procedures. Where Appeals settlement authority has been used on a Joint Committee case, the Appeals official involved in the settlement will be available to respond to inquiries from the Joint Committee regarding the settlement. (
) When the issues are resolved, or a decision is made that a resolution cannot
) the Fast Track Settlement Process (
) When the issues are resolved, or a decision is made that a resolution cannot be reached, the FTS case will be closed promptly. (
) The Appeals official will follow the FTS closing procedures carefully so that both parties are notiﬁed of the outcome. (
) The closing letter will be issued promptly by Appeals to both parties, making certain to date the letter. (
) If the case is unagreed an Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM) will not be prepared, and the administrative ﬁle will be returned to LB&I without Appeals notes prepared to evaluate the issue.
) the FTS Process Settled/Resolved (
) When an agreement is reached, a Fast Track Session Report will be completed by Appeals, reﬂecting the agreement, and all parties will sign the report. (
) If the issue requires a closing agreement, or if the parties request a closing agreement, and Appeals settlement authority was used, Appeals will prepare Form
, Closing Agreement on Final Determination Covering Speciﬁc
Matters or Form
, Agreement as to Final Determination of Tax Liability based on the signed Fast Track Session Report. (

) When closing agreements are used, the taxpayer will sign the agreement, Appeals will execute it on behalf of the government. In cases involving Joint Committee (JC) review, Appeals will suspend its FTS work unit without signing the closing agreement and provide instructions for LB&I to return the closing agreement to Appeals for execution after the JC review process is complete. (
) At the conclusion of the FTS process, Appeals will provide the LB&I team the following: a. Form

(Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo) b. ACM for settled issues c. Executed closing agreement if used (For JC cases, signed by the taxpayer only, and to be signed by Appeals after JC review) d. Completed Fast Track Session Report e. FTS workpapers prepared by Appeals f. Settlement agreements for TEFRA signed by taxpayer (A list of investor names, TINs, and one-year assessment dates will be shown on Form
used to transmit the package to LB&I.) (

) A brief Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM) is prepared for issues settled Appeals settlement authority. a. ACMs prepared for FTS cases will have a brief summary of signiﬁcant facts, body of law relied upon by the parties, and evaluation and recom- mendation as to whether the disposition should be accepted. b. For JC cases, ACMs will be included in the JC Report in support of the settlement reached. c. ACMs will not be prepared for issues resolved within LB&I’s resolution authority, or for unresolved issues. (

) At the completion of the FTS process, LB&I will proceed to complete actions on the overall case. Resolved issues will be incorporated into the RAR, and LB&I will proceed to complete actions on the overall case, as indicated in
) The Appeals FTS participants will complete and submit internal Appeals reporting requirements in accordance with IRM
, Appeals Function. (
) The Appeals FTS program manager will provide a report on the FTS case results to the LB&I issue/case territory manager. The report will consist of Form
, ACM for settled issues, completed FTS Session Report, and a copy of the agreement form. (

) If the Fast Track Settlement process is unsuccessful in resolving/settling an issue, Appeals will send a letter to the taxpayer and LB&I. The letter will who participated in the process, list the issue(s) that were not resolved, and explain the taxpayer’s rights to appeal. This would be done in the case of withdrawn issues as well. (

) At the completion of the FTS process, LB&I will proceed to complete actions on the overall case, as indicated at IRM
) The Appeals FTS participants will complete and submit internal Appeals reporting requirements in accordance with IRM
) A report on the FTS case results will be provided to the LB&I program manager by the Appeals program manager. (
) Special procedures must be followed in cases subject to JC reporting require- ments. General JC procedures under IRM
apply to cases utilizing the Fast Track Process. In addition to, and in conformity with the general JC pro- cedures, the following apply to FTS cases. (

) The FTS Application form provides for the identiﬁcation of potential Joint Committee status. If the Joint Committee criteria are met, or will potentially met upon resolution, the LB&I case manager must so indicate on the FTS plication. (

) Upon assignment of a Fast Track case, Appeals must confer with both the taxpayer and LB&I to determine whether the case is subject to JC reporting requirements and record the results in the ACDS case activity record. (

) At the completion of the Fast Track process, the case status relative to JC reporting will be reconﬁrmed before ﬁnalizing the settlement, taking into consid- eration the results of any issue resolutions reached. (

) Appeals is responsible for preparing the ACM supporting the basis of any settlements reached in Fast Track. Appeals will prepare an ACM that explains ONLY the SETTLED FTS issues in sufficient detail and analysis to apprise JC of the Appeals evaluation and settlement of the Fast Track issues. (

) On the day agreement is reached, the Fast Track Session Report will be completed to document the terms and settlement dollar adjustments. All parties (Appeals, taxpayer and LB&I) will sign off on the Session Report. (

) Appeals will explain to the taxpayer that the settlement is treated as ﬁnal for computation purposes, but that the settlement is subject to review by the con- gressional Joint Committee on Taxation. (
) LB&I may begin preparing the tax computation and the JC Report, incorporat- ing the ACM provided by Appeals. (
) Appeals will close the FTS case on Form
and will give the ACM to LB&I for inclusion in their JC Report. (
) Because the case is in LB&I jurisdiction, LB&I will make the ﬁnal tax computa- tion, and write the JC Report. (
) On the settled issues, Appeals will respond to any concerns raised by the JC regarding the basis for settlement. (

) Issues resolved between the taxpayer and LB&I without using Appeals settle- ment authority (resolved within the LB&I issue manager’s authority), will not have an ACM, and LB&I will respond to JC inquiries and concerns for these issues. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
S (
At the completion of the FTS process, LB&I will proceed to complete actions on the overall case, as indicated at IRM 4.51.4.8.
LB&I/Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program (FTS) 4.51.4 page 21

) Appeals will prepare the closing agreement on settled issues, and solicit the taxpayer’s signature on the closing agreement, but the closing agreement not be signed by Appeals on behalf of the Service until the Joint Committee Taxation clearance letter is received. (
) After the Joint Committee on Taxation completes consideration of the settle- ment, only then will Appeals accept the ﬁnal settlement by executing the closing agreement. (
) When the FTS process is completed and all issues are resolved (or deter- mined to be irresolvable at the LB&I level), LB&I will follow standard closing procedures. (
) At the completion of the FTS process, if further issue/case development is required for FTS or non-FTS issue, it will be completed. (
) For successful FTS cases, resolved issues will be included in the revenue agent’s report (RAR) in accordance with closing agreements and/or Fast Session reports resulting from the FTS process. (
) Issues remaining unresolved will be included in the unagreed RAR, and a day letter will normally be issued inviting the taxpayer to request a traditional Appeals hearing. (
) When some issues are resolved, and other issues remain unagreed, standard partial agreed procedures will be followed in closing the case. (
) When unsuccessful FTS cases come to traditional Appeals, management will decide how to assign the Appeals personnel. Ex parte restriction will not be imposed on intra-Appeals communications. (
